    Censoring

    Robin J. Evans

    31/05/2022

    Censoring.Rmd

    Censoring 

    library(survivl)

    The censoring mechanism is specified either as another outcome variable, or by using the Surv() function in the outcome formula.

    formulas <- list(list(),
                 Z ~ X_l1,
                 X ~ Z_l0,
                 list(Y ~ X_l0, Cen ~ X_l0),
                 cop ~ 1)
family <- list(integer(0), 1, 5, list("weibull", "weibull"), 1)

    The equivalent formulation using Surv() would replace the list in the fourth entry of formulas with Surv(Y,Cen) ~ X_l0.

    The parameters to be specified depends upon the particular families used.

    pars <- list(Z = list(beta=c(-0.25,0.5), phi=1),
             X = list(beta=c(-0.5,0.5)),
             Y = list(beta=c(1.1,-0.2), shape=1, scale=0.5),
             Cen = list(beta=c(0.1,0), shape=1, scale=0.5),
             cop = list(Cen=list(Z=list(beta=0)), Y=list(Z=list(beta=0), Cen=list(beta=0))))

    Now we call the function msm_samp, which uses inversion sampling to obtain data from a marginal structural model with the specified parameters.

    set.seed(123)
dat <- msm_samp(1e5, T=5,
                formulas = formulas, 
                family = family, 
                pars = pars)
# ,
#                 link = list(character(0), "identity", "logit", c("inverse", "inverse")))
datl <- surv_to_long(dat)

    Fitting the Model

    Since this is a time-varying model, we use the appropriate formulation of the model in the coxph() function.

    library(survival)
mod <- coxph(Surv(t, t_stop, Y) ~ X, data = datl, cluster = id)
summary(mod)
    ## Call:
## coxph(formula = Surv(t, t_stop, Y) ~ X, data = datl, cluster = id)
## 
##   n= 204400, number of events= 27087 
## 
##      coef exp(coef) se(coef) robust se     z Pr(>|z|)    
## X 0.21153   1.23557  0.01235   0.01235 17.14   <2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
##   exp(coef) exp(-coef) lower .95 upper .95
## X     1.236     0.8093     1.206     1.266
## 
## Concordance= 0.525  (se = 0.002 )
## Likelihood ratio test= 289.3  on 1 df,   p=<2e-16
## Wald test            = 293.6  on 1 df,   p=<2e-16
## Score (logrank) test = 294.5  on 1 df,   p=<2e-16,   Robust = 280.6  p=<2e-16
## 
##   (Note: the likelihood ratio and score tests assume independence of
##      observations within a cluster, the Wald and robust score tests do not).
